title: 105_s2431
content: The Act may be cited as the "Torture Survivors Relief Act of 1998". The Torture Survivors Relief Act of 1998 acknowledges that torture creates fear and insecurity, destroys individual personality, and is used by repressive governments to suppress opposition and democracy. Survivors of torture face long-term physical and psychological threats, especially when perpetrators are not held accountable. The need for protection for torture survivors and their treatment providers, including refugees and asylees in the United States, to receive prompt consideration for political asylum and rehabilitation services to become productive members of society. The development of a treatment movement for torture survivors has created new opportunities for action by the United States and other nations to oppose state-sponsored and other acts of torture. There is a need for a comprehensive strategy to protect and support torture victims and their treatment providers, together with overall efforts to eliminate torture. By acting to heal the survivors of torture and protect their families, the United States can help to heal the effects of torture and prevent its use around the world. The Act defines "torture" as per section 2340(1) of title 18, U.S. Code, including sexual violence. It introduces assistance for torture victims under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. The President is authorized to provide assistance for the rehabilitation of victims of torture through grants to treatment centers and programs in foreign countries. The assistance can be used for direct services to victims of torture and to provide research and training to health care providers. Funding is authorized for fiscal years 1999 and 2000. Authorized appropriations for fiscal years 1999 and 2000 under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 for the President to carry out section 129, with $5,000,000 allocated for 1999 and $7,500,000 for 2000. Funds remain available until expended. Effective date of the amendment is October 1, 1998. SEC. 5. DOMESTIC TREATMENT CENTERS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may provide grants for services to rehabilitate victims of torture, including physical and psychological treatment, social and legal services, and research/training for healthcare providers. Funding is authorized for fiscal years 1999 and 2000. Funding of $5,000,000 for fiscal year 1999 and $7,500,000 for fiscal year 2000 is authorized for domestic centers and programs assisting victims of torture. Appropriated funds will remain available until expended. SEC. 6. MULTILATERAL ASSISTANCE. Funding authorized for the United Nations Voluntary Fund for Victims of Torture for fiscal years 1999 and 2000 is $3,000,000 each year. The funds will remain available until expended. Congress suggests the President should request the Fund to find new ways to support treatment centers and programs. The United States aims to support treatment centers for torture victims, back the Special Rapporteur on Torture, and establish a mechanism to investigate human rights violations in countries with prevalent torture practices. SEC. 7. SPECIALIZED TRAINING FOR CONSULAR PERSONNEL. The Secretary of State provides training for consular officers on identifying torture, its effects, and interviewing victims without retraumatizing them. Gender-specific training is included in certain cases. Gender-specific training on interacting with victims of torture by rape or sexual violence is provided under subsection (a) (4) or (5).
